Phone-Free Schools.title: An Act amending the act of March 10, 1949 (P.L.30, No.14), known as the Public School Code of 1949, in student supports, providing for bell-to-bell phone-free policy.
Phone-Free Schools.description: Requires all PA public schools to adopt a bell-to-bell phone-free policy by 2027–28. Covers the entire school day including lunch and recess. Schools choose the method (pouches, lockers, etc.) but must restrict possession, not just use. Exceptions for medical needs, IEPs, and English language learners. Passed the Senate 46-1.
Phone-Free Schools.status: In House Education Committee — Referred Feb. 4, 2026

Phone-Free Schools.title: An Act amending the act of March 10, 1949 (P.L.30, No.14), known as the Public School Code of 1949, in pupils and attendance, providing for possession and use of cell phones.
Phone-Free Schools.description: Bans cell phone possession during the school day and requires physical storage — either a lockbox/secure location or a locking pouch carried by the student. More prescriptive than SB1014, which lets districts choose the restriction method. Only exceptions: volunteer firefighters/EMS members and students with an immediate family member's medical condition, both requiring administrator approval.
Phone-Free Schools.status: In House Education Committee — Referred Aug. 20, 2025

Phone-Free Schools.title: An Act amending the act of March 10, 1949 (P.L.30, No.14), known as the Public School Code of 1949, in pupils and attendance, providing for restricting possession and use by students of mobile devices .
Phone-Free Schools.description: Restricts student possession and use of mobile devices during instructional time in K-12 public schools. Sponsored by Rep. Barbara Gleim. Narrower in scope than SB1014 and HB1814, which cover the entire school day bell-to-bell — this bill focuses specifically on instruction time only.
Phone-Free Schools.status: In House Education Committee — Referred April 17, 2025

Phone-Free Schools.title: An Act amending the act of March 10, 1949 (P.L.30, No.14), known as the Public School Code of 1949, in school safety and security, establishing the Cell Phone Lockable Bag Pilot Program.
Phone-Free Schools.nickname: Cell Phone Lockable Bag Pilot Program
Phone-Free Schools.description: Creates a voluntary two-year pilot program providing grants for schools to purchase lockable phone pouches (like Yondr). Participating schools must track and report changes in student mental health, bullying, violence, and academics. Aims for geographic diversity across the state. Expires December 2026.
Phone-Free Schools.status: In Senate Education Committee — Referred Feb. 3, 2025

Social Media Age/Access.title: An Act amending Title 18 (Crimes and Offenses) of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes, providing for guidelines for user age verification and responsible dialogue; providing for the offense of proh ibited promotion of sexually explicit conduct and for the offense of prohibited promotion of violence; and imposing penalties.
Social Media Age/Access.description: Requires age verification on AI chatbots and platforms hosting harmful content. Covered platforms must freeze existing minor accounts and verify age for new ones. Also creates the offenses of prohibited promotion of sexually explicit conduct and violence to minors, with criminal penalties.
Social Media Age/Access.status: In House Communications & Technology Committee — Referred Feb. 11, 2026

Social Media Age/Access.title: An Act amending the act of March 10, 1949 (P.L.30, No.14), known as the Public School Code of 1949, in terms and courses of study, providing for social media literacy education.
Social Media Age/Access.description: Requires PA public schools to provide social media literacy education. Covers topics such as algorithmic manipulation, data privacy, identifying misinformation, and healthy digital habits. Sponsored by Rep. Jim Prokopiak with 14 co-sponsors.
Social Media Age/Access.status: In House Education Committee — Laid on the table Feb. 4, 2026

Social Media Age/Access.title: An Act providing for consumer data privacy, for duties of controllers and for duties of processors; and imposing penalties.
Social Media Age/Access.description: House companion to SB112. Passed the House unanimously. Same framework: comprehensive consumer data privacy protections with specific provisions for children's data, duties for data controllers and processors, and enforcement penalties.
Social Media Age/Access.status: In Senate Communications & Technology Committee — Re-referred Feb. 4, 2026

Social Media Age/Access.title: An Act amending Title 18 (Crimes and Offenses) of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes, in miscellaneous offenses, providing for children's online safety.
Social Media Age/Access.description: Establishes children's online safety protections under PA criminal code. Creates a duty-of-care framework requiring platforms to protect minors from harmful content and exploitative design features.
Social Media Age/Access.status: In House Communications & Technology Committee — Referred July 14, 2025

Social Media Age/Access.title: An Act amending Title 18 (Crimes and Offenses) of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes, in computer offenses, providing for liability for Internet publishers and distributors of material harmful to minors.
Social Media Age/Access.nickname: Liability for Material Harmful to Minors
Social Media Age/Access.description: Creates civil liability for internet publishers and distributors of material harmful to minors. Websites with more than 33% harmful content must verify user ages. Failure to comply can result in treble damages. ISPs, search engines, and cloud providers are exempt.
Social Media Age/Access.status: In House Communications & Technology Committee — Referred May 29, 2025

Social Media Age/Access.title: An Act amending Title 50 (Mental Health) of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes, providing for protection of minors on social media; and imposing penalties.
Social Media Age/Access.nickname: Protection of Minors on Social Media (House companion)
Social Media Age/Access.description: House companion to SB22. Requires parental consent for minors under 16 on social media, bans targeted advertising to kids, and prohibits data collection on minors. Same core framework as SB22 but introduced in the House.
Social Media Age/Access.status: In House Communications & Technology Committee — Referred May 8, 2025

Social Media Age/Access.title: An Act providing for parental consent for virtual mental health services provided by a school entity.
Social Media Age/Access.nickname: Parental Consent for School Virtual Mental Health
Social Media Age/Access.description: Requires schools to get written parental consent before providing any virtual mental health services to students under 18 — including online peer support, non-professional counseling, and AI-based behavioral health tools. Schools must use a standardized consent form renewed annually.
Social Media Age/Access.status: In Senate Education Committee — Referred April 11, 2025

Social Media Age/Access.title: An Act amending Title 18 (Crimes and Offenses) of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes, in computer offenses, providing for Internet protections for minors.
Social Media Age/Access.description: Requires websites where more than one-third of content is harmful to minors to implement age verification (government ID, digital ID, or bank info). Platforms cannot retain identifying data after verification. Exceptions for news organizations and ISPs. Takes effect 90 days after passage.
Social Media Age/Access.status: In Senate Judiciary Committee — Referred April 9, 2025

Social Media Age/Access.title: An Act providing for consumer data privacy, for duties of controllers and for duties of processors; and imposing penalties.
Social Media Age/Access.description: Pennsylvania's comprehensive Consumer Data Privacy Act. Establishes rules for how companies collect, process, and sell personal data, with heightened protections for children's data. Creates duties for data controllers and processors, with penalties for violations. Companion to HB78.
Social Media Age/Access.status: In Senate Communications & Technology Committee — Referred March 21, 2025

Social Media Age/Access.title: An Act amending the the act of October 24, 2012 (P.L.1209, No.151), known as the Child Labor Act, further providing for definitions and for employment of minors in a performance; and providing for emp loyment of minors as content creators.
Social Media Age/Access.description: Extends child labor protections to minors who are social media content creators. Requires parents or guardians to set aside a portion of the child's earnings in a trust account, inaccessible until the child turns 18. Part of a multi-state trend following Illinois and California kidfluencer laws.
Social Media Age/Access.status: In House Labor & Industry Committee — Referred March 17, 2025

Social Media Age/Access.title: An Act amending Title 50 (Mental Health) of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes, providing for protection of minors on social media; and imposing penalties.
Social Media Age/Access.nickname: Protection of Minors on Social Media
Social Media Age/Access.description: Prohibits social media accounts for children under 16 without parental consent. Parents can revoke consent and demand account closure. Bans platforms from mining or selling minors' data and from showing content that could harm their mental health. Enforced by the Attorney General with civil penalties; parents can also sue.
Social Media Age/Access.status: In Senate Communications & Technology Committee — Referred Jan. 24, 2025

EdTech & AI in Schools.title: An Act providing for a report on artificial intelligence in the workforce; and imposing duties on the Department of Labor and Industry and Department of Community and Economic Development.
EdTech & AI in Schools.description: Commissions a study on the impact of artificial intelligence on Pennsylvania's workforce and education system, including how AI tools are being used in schools and potential effects on student learning.
EdTech & AI in Schools.lastAction: Laid on the table (Pursuant to Senate Rule 9), Feb. 2, 2026
EdTech & AI in Schools.status: In Senate Labor & Industry Committee — Laid on the table (Pursuant to Senate Rule 9) Feb. 2, 2026

EdTech & AI in Schools.title: An Act amending Title 24 (Education) of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes, in preliminary provisions, providing for student data privacy and protection; conferring powers and imposing duties on t he Department of Education; and imposing penalties.
EdTech & AI in Schools.description: Comprehensive student data privacy law. Requires the Dept. of Education to appoint a chief data privacy officer. Schools must adopt security measures, designate a data manager, and file annual reports. Defines student data broadly (including biometrics) and limits how ed-tech companies can collect, use, and share it. Includes penalties for noncompliance.
EdTech & AI in Schools.status: In Senate Education Committee — Referred Feb. 26, 2025

Online Safety.title: An Act providing for civil liability for fraudulent misrepresentation of candidates; and imposing penalties.
Online Safety.description: Creates civil liability for AI-generated deepfakes that misrepresent someone. Builds on PA's 2024 deepfake law (Act 125) and 2025 Act 35, which criminalized deepfakes with fraudulent intent. Includes specific protections for minors against AI-generated CSAM and non-consensual intimate images.
Online Safety.status: In Senate Communications & Technology Committee — Referred June 24, 2025

Online Safety.title: An Act amending the act of November 22, 1978 (P.L.1166, No.274), referred to as the Pennsylvania Commission on Crime and Delinquency Law, providing for Investigation and Prosecution of Internet Crimes Against Children Program.
Online Safety.description: Named for Alicia Kozakiewicz, who was abducted by an internet predator at age 13. Establishes an ICAC (Internet Crimes Against Children) program within PCCD, funded by grants for state and local task forces to investigate and prosecute technology-facilitated child exploitation. Supplements existing federal ICAC funding.
Online Safety.status: In House Judiciary Committee — Laid on the table May 5, 2025

Childhood Independence.title: An Act amending the act of March 10, 1949 (P.L.30, No.14), known as the Public School Code of 1949, in terms and courses of study, providing for recess and lunch periods.
Childhood Independence.description: Requires all PA public schools — K through 12 — to provide at least 30 minutes of recess and 30 minutes for lunch every school day. Notably extends the recess requirement to middle and high school students, not just elementary.
Childhood Independence.status: In House Education Committee — Referred Feb. 12, 2026

Childhood Independence.title: An Act amending Titles 18 (Crimes and Offenses), 23 (Domestic Relations) and 42 (Judiciary and Judicial Procedure) of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes, in offenses against the family, further pr oviding for the offense of endangering welfare of children; in child protective services, further providing for definitions and for exclusions from child abuse; and, in juvenile matters, further providing for definitions.
Childhood Independence.description: Amends child abuse and neglect definitions so that parents aren't penalized for allowing age-appropriate independence — such as walking to school, playing outside unsupervised, or babysitting. Requires prosecutors to show willful or reckless disregard for obvious danger, not just a child being unsupervised. Aims to curb CPS overreach that disproportionately impacts non-white and working families.
Childhood Independence.status: In House Children & Youth Committee — Laid on the table Nov. 18, 2025

Childhood Independence.title: An Act amending the act of March 10, 1949 (P.L.30, No.14), known as the Public School Code of 1949, in terms and courses of study, providing for free-play recess.
Childhood Independence.description: Mandates at least 30 minutes of daily unstructured free-play recess for elementary students. Focuses specifically on child-directed play rather than organized activities, citing benefits for physical health, concentration, and social-emotional development.
Childhood Independence.status: In House Education Committee — Referred June 25, 2025
